title.raw: 《曹相國世家》 House of Chancellor Cao

sentences.zh: 平陽侯曹參者，沛人也。

translations.literal: Marquis Pingyang Cao Can was a native of Pei.

sentences.zh: 秦時為沛獄掾，而蕭何為主吏，居縣為豪吏矣。

translations.literal: During Qin times he served as assistant jailer in Pei, while Xiao He was the chief clerk—they were both outstanding officials in the county.
Marquis Pingyang Cao Can was a native of Pei. During Qin times he served as assistant jailer in Pei, while Xiao He was the chief clerk—they were both outstanding officials in the county.

sentences.zh: 高祖為沛公而初起也，參以中涓從。

translations.literal: When Gaozu rose as Duke of Pei, Cao Can followed as an attendant.

sentences.zh: 將擊胡陵、方與，攻秦監公軍，大破之。

translations.literal: He led attacks on Huling and Fangyu, assaulting the Qin Inspector's army and greatly defeating it.

sentences.zh: 東下薛，擊泗水守軍薛郭西。

translations.literal: He advanced east to Xue, attacking the garrison of the Si River warden west of Xue's outer walls.

sentences.zh: 復攻胡陵，取之。

translations.literal: He attacked Huling again and captured it.

sentences.zh: 徙守方與。

translations.literal: He was transferred to defend Fangyu.

sentences.zh: 方與反為魏，擊之。

translations.literal: Fangyu defected to Wei, so he attacked it.

sentences.zh: 豐反為魏，攻之。

translations.literal: Feng defected to Wei, so he attacked it.

sentences.zh: 賜爵七大夫。

translations.literal: He was granted the rank of Seventh Rank Noble.

sentences.zh: 擊秦司馬夷軍碭東，破之，取碭、狐父、祁善置。

translations.literal: He attacked the Qin Marshal Yi's army east of Dang, defeated it, and captured Dang, Hufu, and Qishanzhi.

sentences.zh: 又攻下邑以西，至虞，擊章邯車騎。

translations.literal: He further attacked west from Xiayi to Yu, attacking Zhang Han's chariots and cavalry.

sentences.zh: 攻爰戚及亢父，先登。

translations.literal: He attacked Yuanqi and Kangfu, being first to scale the walls.

sentences.zh: 遷為五大夫。

translations.literal: He was promoted to Fifth Rank Noble.

sentences.zh: 北救阿，擊章邯軍，陷陳，追至濮陽。

translations.literal: He went north to rescue E, attacked Zhang Han's army, broke through their formations, and pursued to Puyang.

sentences.zh: 攻定陶，取臨濟。

translations.literal: He attacked Dingtao and captured Linji.

sentences.zh: 南救雍丘。

translations.literal: He went south to rescue Yongqiu.

sentences.zh: 擊李由軍，破之，殺李由，虜秦候一人。

translations.literal: He attacked Li You's army, defeated it, killed Li You, and captured one Qin noble.

sentences.zh: 秦將章邯破殺項梁也，沛公與項羽引而東。

translations.literal: When Qin general Zhang Han defeated and killed Xiang Liang, the Duke of Pei and Xiang Yu led their armies east.

sentences.zh: 楚懷王以沛公為碭郡長，將碭郡兵。

translations.literal: King Huai of Chu appointed the Duke of Pei as governor of Dang commandery to lead Dang commandery troops.

sentences.zh: 於是乃封參為執帛，號曰建成君。

translations.literal: Thus he enfeoffed Cao Can as Holder of Silk, with the title Lord Jiancheng.

sentences.zh: 遷為戚公，屬碭郡。

translations.literal: He was promoted to Duke of Qi, belonging to Dang commandery.

When Gaozu rose as Duke of Pei, Cao Can followed as an attendant. He led attacks on Huling and Fangyu, assaulting the Qin Inspector's army and greatly defeating it. He advanced east to Xue, attacking the garrison of the Si River warden west of Xue's outer walls. He attacked Huling again and captured it. He was transferred to defend Fangyu. Fangyu defected to Wei, so he attacked it. Feng defected to Wei, so he attacked it. He was granted the rank of Seventh Rank Noble. He attacked the Qin Marshal Yi's army east of Dang, defeated it, and captured Dang, Hufu, and Qishanzhi. He further attacked west from Xiayi to Yu, attacking Zhang Han's chariots and cavalry. He attacked Yuanqi and Kangfu, being first to scale the walls. He was promoted to Fifth Rank Noble. He went north to rescue E, attacked Zhang Han's army, broke through their formations, and pursued to Puyang. He attacked Dingtao and captured Linji. He went south to rescue Yongqiu. He attacked Li You's army, defeated it, killed Li You, and captured one Qin noble. When Qin general Zhang Han defeated and killed Xiang Liang, the Duke of Pei and Xiang Yu led their armies east. King Huai of Chu appointed the Duke of Pei as governor of Dang commandery to lead Dang commandery troops. Thus he enfeoffed Cao Can as Holder of Silk, with the title Lord Jiancheng. He was promoted to Duke of Qi, belonging to Dang commandery.

sentences.zh: 其後從攻東郡尉軍，破之成武南。

translations.literal: Afterwards he followed in attacking the Dongjun warden's army, defeating it south of Chengwu.

sentences.zh: 擊王離軍成陽南，復攻之杠裏，大破之。

translations.literal: He attacked Wang Li's army south of Chengyang, then attacked it again at Gangli, greatly defeating it.

sentences.zh: 追北，西至開封，擊趙賁軍，破之，圍趙賁開封城中。

translations.literal: He pursued north, west to Kaifeng, attacked Zhao Ben's army, defeated it, and besieged Zhao Ben in Kaifeng city.

sentences.zh: 西擊將楊熊軍於曲遇，破之，虜秦司馬及御史各一人。

translations.literal: He attacked General Yang Xiong's army at Quyü to the west, defeated it, and captured one Qin marshal and one imperial secretary each.

sentences.zh: 遷為執珪。

translations.literal: He was promoted to Holder of Jade.

sentences.zh: 從攻陽武，下軒轅、緱氏，絕河津，還擊趙賁軍尸北，破之。

translations.literal: He followed in attacking Yangwu, captured Xuanyuan and Goushi, cut off the river crossings, returned to attack Zhao Ben's army north of Shi, and defeated it.

sentences.zh: 從南攻犨，與南陽守齮戰陽城郭東，陷陳，取宛，虜齮，盡定南陽郡。

translations.literal: He followed south attacking Yan, fought with the Nanyang warden Yi east of Yangcheng's outer walls, broke through formations, captured Wan, captured Yi, and completely pacified Nanyang commandery.

sentences.zh: 從西攻武關、峣關，取之。

translations.literal: He followed west attacking Wuguan and Yaoguan, capturing them.

sentences.zh: 前攻秦軍藍田南，又夜擊其北，秦軍大破，遂至咸陽，滅秦。

translations.literal: He advanced attacking the Qin army south of Lantian, then at night attacked its north, the Qin army was greatly defeated, thus reaching Xianyang and destroying Qin.

Afterwards he followed in attacking the Dongjun warden's army, defeating it south of Chengwu. He attacked Wang Li's army south of Chengyang, then attacked it again at Gangli, greatly defeating it. He pursued north, west to Kaifeng, attacked Zhao Ben's army, defeated it, and besieged Zhao Ben in Kaifeng city. He attacked General Yang Xiong's army at Quyü to the west, defeated it, and captured one Qin marshal and one imperial secretary each. He was promoted to Holder of Jade. He followed in attacking Yangwu, captured Xuanyuan and Goushi, cut off the river crossings, returned to attack Zhao Ben's army north of Shi, and defeated it. He followed south attacking Yan, fought with the Nanyang warden Yi east of Yangcheng's outer walls, broke through formations, captured Wan, captured Yi, and completely pacified Nanyang commandery. He followed west attacking Wuguan and Yaoguan, capturing them. He advanced attacking the Qin army south of Lantian, then at night attacked its north, the Qin army was greatly defeated, thus reaching Xianyang and destroying Qin.

sentences.zh: 項羽至，以沛公為漢王。

translations.literal: When Xiang Yu arrived, he made the Duke of Pei King of Han.

sentences.zh: 漢王封參為建成侯。

translations.literal: The King of Han enfeoffed Cao Can as Marquis of Jiancheng.

sentences.zh: 從至漢中，遷為將軍。

translations.literal: He followed to Hanzhong, promoted to general.

sentences.zh: 從還定三秦，初攻下辯、故道、雍、斄。

translations.literal: He followed returning to pacify the Three Qins, initially attacking and capturing Bian, Gudao, Yong, and Lai.

sentences.zh: 擊章平軍於好畤南，破之，圍好畤，取壤鄉。

translations.literal: He attacked Zhang Ping's army south of Haozhi, defeated it, besieged Haozhi, and captured Rangxiang.

sentences.zh: 擊三秦軍壤東及高櫟，破之。

translations.literal: He attacked the Three Qins army east of Rang and at Gaoque, defeating it.

sentences.zh: 復圍章平，章平出好畤走。

translations.literal: He besieged Zhang Ping again, Zhang Ping fled from Haozhi.

sentences.zh: 因擊趙賁、內史保軍，破之。

translations.literal: He then attacked Zhao Ben and Grand Administrator Bao's army, defeating it.

sentences.zh: 東取咸陽，更名曰新城。

translations.literal: He captured Xianyang to the east, renaming it New City.

sentences.zh: 參將兵守景陵二十日，三秦使章平等攻參，參出擊，大破之。

translations.literal: Cao Can led troops guarding Jingling for twenty days, the Three Qins sent Zhang Ping and others to attack Cao Can, Cao Can sallied to attack, greatly defeating them.

sentences.zh: 賜食邑於寧秦。

translations.literal: He was granted fief income in Ningqin.

sentences.zh: 參以將軍引兵圍章邯於廢丘。

translations.literal: Cao Can as general led troops besieging Zhang Han at Fei Qiu.

sentences.zh: 以中尉從漢王出臨晉關。

translations.literal: As Commandant he followed the King of Han out of Linjin Pass.

sentences.zh: 至河內，下修武，渡圍津，東擊龍且、項他定陶，破之。

translations.literal: Arriving in Hebei, he captured Xiuwu, crossed at Wei Jin, attacked Long Ju and Xiang Ta at Dingtao to the east, defeating them.

sentences.zh: 東取碭、蕭、彭城。

translations.literal: He captured Dang, Xiao, and Pengcheng to the east.

sentences.zh: 擊項籍軍，漢軍大敗走。

translations.literal: He attacked Xiang Yu's army, the Han army suffered great defeat and fled.

sentences.zh: 參以中尉圍取雍丘。

translations.literal: Cao Can as Commandant besieged and captured Yongqiu.

sentences.zh: 王武反於［外］黃，程處反於燕，往擊，盡破之。

translations.literal: Wang Wu rebelled at Waihuang, Cheng Chu rebelled at Yan, he went to attack them, completely defeating both.

sentences.zh: 柱天侯反於衍氏，又進破取衍氏。

translations.literal: Marquis Zhutian rebelled at Yanshi, he advanced and defeated and captured Yanshi.

sentences.zh: 擊羽嬰於昆陽，追至葉。

translations.literal: He attacked Yu Ying at Kunyang, pursuing to Ye.

sentences.zh: 還攻武彊，因至滎陽。

translations.literal: He returned attacking Wujiang, thus reaching Xingyang.

sentences.zh: 參自漢中為將軍中尉，從擊諸侯，及項羽敗，還至滎陽，凡二歲。

translations.literal: Cao Can from Hanzhong served as General Commandant, following to attack the feudal lords, and when Xiang Yu was defeated, returned to Xingyang, altogether two years.

When Xiang Yu arrived, he made the Duke of Pei King of Han. The King of Han enfeoffed Cao Can as Marquis of Jiancheng. He followed to Hanzhong, promoted to general. He followed returning to pacify the Three Qins, initially attacking and capturing Bian, Gudao, Yong, and Lai. He attacked Zhang Ping's army south of Haozhi, defeated it, besieged Haozhi, and captured Rangxiang. He attacked the Three Qins army east of Rang and at Gaoque, defeating it. He besieged Zhang Ping again, Zhang Ping fled from Haozhi. He then attacked Zhao Ben and Grand Administrator Bao's army, defeating it. He captured Xianyang to the east, renaming it New City. Cao Can led troops guarding Jingling for twenty days, the Three Qins sent Zhang Ping and others to attack Cao Can, Cao Can sallied to attack, greatly defeating them. He was granted fief income in Ningqin. Cao Can as general led troops besieging Zhang Han at Fei Qiu. As Commandant he followed the King of Han out of Linjin Pass. Arriving in Hebei, he captured Xiuwu, crossed at Wei Jin, attacked Long Ju and Xiang Ta at Dingtao to the east, defeating them. He captured Dang, Xiao, and Pengcheng to the east. He attacked Xiang Yu's army, the Han army suffered great defeat and fled. Cao Can as Commandant besieged and captured Yongqiu. Wang Wu rebelled at Waihuang, Cheng Chu rebelled at Yan, he went to attack them, completely defeating both. Marquis Zhutian rebelled at Yanshi, he advanced and defeated and captured Yanshi. He attacked Yu Ying at Kunyang, pursuing to Ye. He returned attacking Wujiang, thus reaching Xingyang. Cao Can from Hanzhong served as General Commandant, following to attack the feudal lords, and when Xiang Yu was defeated, returned to Xingyang, altogether two years.

sentences.zh: 高祖（三）［二］年，拜為假左丞相，入屯兵關中。

translations.literal: In Gaozu year 2, he was appointed Acting Left Chancellor, entering to station troops in Guanzhong.

sentences.zh: 月餘，魏王豹反，以假左丞相別與韓信東攻魏將軍孫遬軍東張，大破之。

translations.literal: After more than a month, King Wei Bao rebelled, so as Acting Left Chancellor he separately went east with Han Xin to attack Wei general Sun Ju's army at Dongzhang, greatly defeating it.

sentences.zh: 因攻安邑，得魏將王襄。

translations.literal: He then attacked Anyi, capturing Wei general Wang Xiang.

sentences.zh: 擊魏王於曲陽，追至武垣，生得魏王豹。

translations.literal: He attacked the King of Wei at Quyang, pursuing to Wuyuan, capturing the King of Wei Bao alive.

sentences.zh: 取平陽，得魏王母妻子，盡定魏地，凡五十二城。

translations.literal: He captured Pingyang, obtaining the King of Wei's mother, wife, and children, completely pacifying Wei territory, altogether fifty-two cities.

sentences.zh: 賜食邑平陽。

translations.literal: He was granted fief income in Pingyang.

sentences.zh: 因從韓信擊趙相國夏說軍於鄔東，大破之，斬夏說。

translations.literal: He then followed Han Xin attacking Chancellor of Zhao Xia Yue's army east of Wu, greatly defeating it, beheading Xia Yue.

sentences.zh: 韓信與故常山王張耳引兵下井陘，擊成安君，而令參還圍趙別將戚將軍於鄔城中。

translations.literal: Han Xin and former King Changshan Zhang Er led troops down Jingxing, attacking Lord Cheng'an, while ordering Cao Can to return and besiege Zhao's separate general Lord Qi in Wu city.

sentences.zh: 戚將軍出走，追斬之。

translations.literal: Lord Qi fled, he pursued and beheaded him.

sentences.zh: 乃引兵詣敖倉漢王之所。

translations.literal: He then led troops to Aocang where the King of Han was located.

sentences.zh: 韓信已破趙，為相國，東擊齊。

translations.literal: Han Xin had already defeated Zhao, became Chancellor, attacking Qi to the east.

sentences.zh: 參以右丞相屬韓信，攻破齊歷下軍，遂取臨菑。

translations.literal: Cao Can as Right Chancellor under Han Xin attacked and broke the Qi army at Lixia, thus capturing Linzi.

sentences.zh: 還定濟北郡，攻著、漯陰、平原、鬲、盧。

translations.literal: He returned to pacify Jibei commandery, attacking Zhu, Taoyin, Pingyuan, Ge, and Lu.

sentences.zh: 已而從韓信擊龍且軍於上假密，大破之，斬龍且，虜其將軍周蘭。

translations.literal: Soon after he followed Han Xin attacking Long Ju's army at Shang Jiami, greatly defeating it, beheading Long Ju, capturing his general Zhou Lan.

sentences.zh: 定齊，凡得七十餘縣。

translations.literal: He pacified Qi, altogether obtaining over seventy counties.

sentences.zh: 得故齊王田廣相田光，其守相許章，及故齊膠東將軍田既。

translations.literal: He captured former Qi King Tian Guang's chancellor Tian Guang, his defending chancellor Xu Zhang, and former Qi Jiaodong general Tian Ji.

sentences.zh: 韓信為齊王，引兵詣陳，與漢王共破項羽，而參留平齊未服者。

translations.literal: Han Xin became King of Qi, led troops to Chen, together with the King of Han defeated Xiang Yu, while Cao Can remained to pacify those in Qi who had not submitted.

In Gaozu year 2, he was appointed Acting Left Chancellor, entering to station troops in Guanzhong. After more than a month, King Wei Bao rebelled, so as Acting Left Chancellor he separately went east with Han Xin to attack Wei general Sun Ju's army at Dongzhang, greatly defeating it. He then attacked Anyi, capturing Wei general Wang Xiang. He attacked the King of Wei at Quyang, pursuing to Wuyuan, capturing the King of Wei Bao alive. He captured Pingyang, obtaining the King of Wei's mother, wife, and children, completely pacifying Wei territory, altogether fifty-two cities. He was granted fief income in Pingyang. He then followed Han Xin attacking Chancellor of Zhao Xia Yue's army east of Wu, greatly defeating it, beheading Xia Yue. Han Xin and former King Changshan Zhang Er led troops down Jingxing, attacking Lord Cheng'an, while ordering Cao Can to return and besiege Zhao's separate general Lord Qi in Wu city. Lord Qi fled, he pursued and beheaded him. He then led troops to Aocang where the King of Han was located. Han Xin had already defeated Zhao, became Chancellor, attacking Qi to the east. Cao Can as Right Chancellor under Han Xin attacked and broke the Qi army at Lixia, thus capturing Linzi. He returned to pacify Jibei commandery, attacking Zhu, Taoyin, Pingyuan, Ge, and Lu. Soon after he followed Han Xin attacking Long Ju's army at Shang Jiami, greatly defeating it, beheading Long Ju, capturing his general Zhou Lan. He pacified Qi, altogether obtaining over seventy counties. He captured former Qi King Tian Guang's chancellor Tian Guang, his defending chancellor Xu Zhang, and former Qi Jiaodong general Tian Ji. Han Xin became King of Qi, led troops to Chen, together with the King of Han defeated Xiang Yu, while Cao Can remained to pacify those in Qi who had not submitted.

sentences.zh: 項籍已死，天下定，漢王為皇帝，韓信徙為楚王，齊為郡。

translations.literal: After Xiang Ji died and the realm was pacified, the King of Han became emperor, Han Xin was moved to King of Chu, Qi became a commandery.

sentences.zh: 參歸漢相印。

translations.literal: Cao Can returned the Han chancellorship seal.

sentences.zh: 高帝以長子肥為齊王，而以參為齊相國。

translations.literal: Gaozu made his eldest son Fei King of Qi, and appointed Cao Can as Qi's prime minister.

sentences.zh: 以高祖六年賜爵列侯，與諸侯剖符，世世勿絕。

translations.literal: In Gaozu year 6 he was granted marquis rank, sharing the tally with feudal lords, never to be extinguished generation after generation.

sentences.zh: 食邑平陽萬六百三十戶，號曰平陽侯，除前所食邑。

translations.literal: His fief income was Pingyang with 16,630 households, titled Marquis of Pingyang, removing his previous fief income.

After Xiang Ji died and the realm was pacified, the King of Han became emperor, Han Xin was moved to King of Chu, Qi became a commandery. Cao Can returned the Han chancellorship seal. Gaozu made his eldest son Fei King of Qi, and appointed Cao Can as Qi's prime minister. In Gaozu year 6 he was granted marquis rank, sharing the tally with feudal lords, never to be extinguished generation after generation. His fief income was Pingyang with 16,630 households, titled Marquis of Pingyang, removing his previous fief income.

sentences.zh: 以齊相國擊陳豨將張春軍，破之。

translations.literal: As Qi prime minister he attacked Chen Xi's general Zhang Chun's army, defeating it.

sentences.zh: 黥布反，參以齊相國從悼惠王將兵車騎十二萬人，與高祖會擊黥布軍，大破之。

translations.literal: Ying Bu rebelled, Cao Can as Qi prime minister followed King Daohui leading troops and chariots of 120,000 men, meeting with Gaozu to attack Ying Bu's army, greatly defeating it.

sentences.zh: 南至蘄，還定竹邑、相、蕭、留。

translations.literal: He went south to Qi, returning to pacify Zhuyi, Xiang, Xiao, and Liu.

As Qi prime minister he attacked Chen Xi's general Zhang Chun's army, defeating it. Ying Bu rebelled, Cao Can as Qi prime minister followed King Daohui leading troops and chariots of 120,000 men, meeting with Gaozu to attack Ying Bu's army, greatly defeating it. He went south to Qi, returning to pacify Zhuyi, Xiang, Xiao, and Liu.

sentences.zh: 參功：凡下二國，縣一百二十二；

translations.literal: Cao Can's merits: Altogether conquered two states, 122 counties;

sentences.zh: 得王二人，相三人，將軍六人，大莫敖、郡守、司馬、候、御史各一人。

translations.literal: captured two kings, three chancellors, six generals, one Grand Moao, one commandery governor, one marshal, one noble, one imperial secretary each.

Cao Can's merits: Altogether conquered two states, 122 counties; captured two kings, three chancellors, six generals, one Grand Moao, one commandery governor, one marshal, one noble, one imperial secretary each.

sentences.zh: 孝惠帝元年，除諸侯相國法，更以參為齊丞相。

translations.literal: In Emperor Hui year 1, the law for feudal lords' prime ministers was abolished, changing Cao Can to Qi chancellor.

sentences.zh: 參之相齊，齊七十城。

translations.literal: When Cao Can served as chancellor of Qi, Qi had seventy cities.

sentences.zh: 天下初定，悼惠王富於春秋，參盡召長老諸生，問所以安集百姓，如齊故［俗］諸儒以百數，言人人殊，參未知所定。

translations.literal: The realm had just been pacified, King Daohui was young, Cao Can summoned all the elders and scholars, asking how to pacify and gather the people, scholars of Qi custom numbered in the hundreds, each speaking differently, Cao Can did not know what to decide.

sentences.zh: 聞膠西有蓋公，善治黃老言，使人厚幣請之。

translations.literal: He heard there was Master Gai in Jiaoxi who was skilled in Huang-Lao teachings, sent people with generous gifts to invite him.

sentences.zh: 既見蓋公，蓋公為言治道貴清靜而民自定，推此類具言之。

translations.literal: When he met Master Gai, Master Gai spoke of the way of governance valuing tranquility and the people naturally settling, elaborating on this category comprehensively.

sentences.zh: 參於是避正堂，舍蓋公焉。

translations.literal: Thus Cao Can vacated the main hall and housed Master Gai there.

sentences.zh: 其治要用黃老術，故相齊九年，齊國安集，大稱賢相。

translations.literal: His governance essentials used Huang-Lao methods, thus serving as chancellor of Qi for nine years, Qi was pacified and stable, greatly acclaimed as a worthy chancellor.

In Emperor Hui year 1, the law for feudal lords' prime ministers was abolished, changing Cao Can to Qi chancellor. When Cao Can served as chancellor of Qi, Qi had seventy cities. The realm had just been pacified, King Daohui was young, Cao Can summoned all the elders and scholars, asking how to pacify and gather the people, scholars of Qi custom numbered in the hundreds, each speaking differently, Cao Can did not know what to decide. He heard there was Master Gai in Jiaoxi who was skilled in Huang-Lao teachings, sent people with generous gifts to invite him. When he met Master Gai, Master Gai spoke of the way of governance valuing tranquility and the people naturally settling, elaborating on this category comprehensively. Thus Cao Can vacated the main hall and housed Master Gai there. His governance essentials used Huang-Lao methods, thus serving as chancellor of Qi for nine years, Qi was pacified and stable, greatly acclaimed as a worthy chancellor.

sentences.zh: 惠帝二年，蕭何卒。

translations.literal: In Emperor Hui year 2, Xiao He died.

sentences.zh: 參聞之，告舍人趣治行，「吾將入相」。

translations.literal: Cao Can heard of it, told his retainers to quickly prepare for travel, 'I will enter as prime minister.'

sentences.zh: 居無何，使者果召參。

translations.literal: Before long, envoys indeed summoned Cao Can.

sentences.zh: 參去，屬其後相曰：「以齊獄市為寄，慎勿擾也。」

translations.literal: Cao Can departed, instructing his successor chancellor: 'Consider Qi's prisons and markets as entrusted, do not disturb them.'

sentences.zh: 後相曰：「治無大於此者乎？」

translations.literal: The successor chancellor said: 'Is there nothing more important than this in governance?'

sentences.zh: 參曰：「不然。

translations.literal: Cao Can said: 'Not so.

sentences.zh: 夫獄市者，所以并容也，今君擾之，姦人安所容也？

translations.literal: Prisons and markets are for containing all sorts—now if you disturb them, where will wicked people find containment?

sentences.zh: 吾是以先之。」

translations.literal: This is why I put it first.'

In Emperor Hui year 2, Xiao He died. Cao Can heard of it, told his retainers to quickly prepare for travel, 'I will enter as prime minister.' Before long, envoys indeed summoned Cao Can. Cao Can departed, instructing his successor chancellor: 'Consider Qi's prisons and markets as entrusted, do not disturb them.' The successor chancellor said: 'Is there nothing more important than this in governance?' Cao Can said: 'Not so. Prisons and markets are for containing all sorts—now if you disturb them, where will wicked people find containment? This is why I put it first.'

sentences.zh: 參始微時，與蕭何善；

translations.literal: Cao Can from humble beginnings was on good terms with Xiao He;

sentences.zh: 及為將相，有卻。

translations.literal: when they became generals and chancellors, there was some distance.

sentences.zh: 至何且死，所推賢唯參。

translations.literal: When Xiao He was about to die, the worthy he recommended was only Cao Can.

sentences.zh: 參代何為漢相國，舉事無所變更，一遵蕭何約束。

translations.literal: Cao Can succeeded Xiao He as Han prime minister, in handling affairs he changed nothing, strictly following Xiao He's regulations.

Cao Can from humble beginnings was on good terms with Xiao He; when they became generals and chancellors, there was some distance. When Xiao He was about to die, the worthy he recommended was only Cao Can. Cao Can succeeded Xiao He as Han prime minister, in handling affairs he changed nothing, strictly following Xiao He's regulations.

sentences.zh: 擇郡國吏木詘於文辭，重厚長者，即召除為丞相史。

translations.literal: He selected commandery and state officials who were clumsy with literary phrases, solid and mature elders, immediately summoning and appointing them as chancellor secretaries.

sentences.zh: 吏之言文刻深，欲務聲名者，輒斥去之。

translations.literal: Officials who spoke of literary precision and harshness, desiring to pursue reputation, he immediately dismissed them.

sentences.zh: 日夜飲醇酒。

translations.literal: Day and night he drank strong wine.

sentences.zh: 卿大夫已下吏及賓客見參不事事，來者皆欲有言。

translations.literal: Ministers, grandees, and lower officials as well as guests saw Cao Can doing nothing, visitors all wished to speak.

sentences.zh: 至者，參輒飲以醇酒，閒之，欲有所言，復飲之，醉而後去，終莫得開說，以為常。

translations.literal: Those who arrived, Cao Can always gave them strong wine to drink, made them relaxed—if they wished to speak, gave them more to drink, they left drunk, never able to speak their minds, this became the norm.

He selected commandery and state officials who were clumsy with literary phrases, solid and mature elders, immediately summoning and appointing them as chancellor secretaries. Officials who spoke of literary precision and harshness, desiring to pursue reputation, he immediately dismissed them. Day and night he drank strong wine. Ministers, grandees, and lower officials as well as guests saw Cao Can doing nothing, visitors all wished to speak. Those who arrived, Cao Can always gave them strong wine to drink, made them relaxed—if they wished to speak, gave them more to drink, they left drunk, never able to speak their minds, this became the norm.

sentences.zh: 相舍後園近吏舍，吏舍日飲歌呼。

translations.literal: The prime minister's residence back garden was near the official quarters, the official quarters daily drank and sang loudly.

sentences.zh: 從吏惡之，無如之何，乃請參游園中，聞吏醉歌呼，從吏幸相國召按之。

translations.literal: The attendants hated it, but could do nothing about it, so they requested Cao Can to stroll in the garden, hearing the officials drunk singing loudly, hoping the prime minister would summon and investigate them.

sentences.zh: 乃反取酒張坐飲，亦歌呼與相應和。

translations.literal: Instead he brought wine and spread mats to sit and drink, also singing loudly in response and harmony.

The prime minister's residence back garden was near the official quarters, the official quarters daily drank and sang loudly. The attendants hated it, but could do nothing about it, so they requested Cao Can to stroll in the garden, hearing the officials drunk singing loudly, hoping the prime minister would summon and investigate them. Instead he brought wine and spread mats to sit and drink, also singing loudly in response and harmony.

sentences.zh: 參見人之有細過，專掩匿覆蓋之，府中無事。

translations.literal: When Cao Can saw people with minor faults, he specially concealed and covered them up, the office had no affairs.
When Cao Can saw people with minor faults, he specially concealed and covered them up, the office had no affairs.

sentences.zh: 參子窋為中大夫。

translations.literal: Cao Can's son Jiu served as middle grandee.

sentences.zh: 惠帝怪相國不治事，以為「豈少朕與」？

translations.literal: Emperor Hui was surprised the prime minister did not handle affairs, thinking 'Is it that he despises me?'

sentences.zh: 乃謂窋曰：「若歸，試私從容問而父曰：『高帝新棄群臣，帝富於春秋，君為相，日飲，無所請事，何以憂天下乎？』

translations.literal: He then told Jiu: 'When you return, try privately and leisurely ask your father: 'Gaozu has newly abandoned the ministers, the emperor is young, you serve as prime minister, daily drinking, having no affairs to request, how do you worry about the realm?'

sentences.zh: 然無言吾告若也。」

translations.literal: However do not say I told you.'

sentences.zh: 窋既洗沐歸，窋侍，自從其所諫參。

translations.literal: Jiu having bathed and returned, while attending, privately followed his instructions to remonstrate with Cao Can.

sentences.zh: 參怒，而笞窋二百，曰：「趣入侍，天下事非若所當言也。」

translations.literal: Cao Can was angry and caned Jiu two hundred strokes, saying: 'Hurry and enter to attend—the affairs of the realm are not for you to speak of.'

sentences.zh: 至朝時，惠帝讓參曰：「與窋胡治乎？

translations.literal: At court, Emperor Hui reproached Cao Can: 'Why did you cane Jiu?

sentences.zh: 乃者我使諫君也。」

translations.literal: It was I who sent him to remonstrate with you.'

sentences.zh: 參免冠謝曰：「陛下自察聖武孰與高帝？」

translations.literal: Cao Can removed his cap and apologized: 'Your majesty yourself examine—whose sagely martial qualities compare with Gaozu's?'

sentences.zh: 上曰：「朕乃安敢望先帝乎！」

translations.literal: The emperor said: 'How would I dare aspire to the former emperor!'

sentences.zh: 曰：「陛下觀臣能孰與蕭何賢？」

translations.literal: He said: 'Your majesty observe—whose ability compares with Xiao He's worthiness?'

sentences.zh: 上曰：「君似不及也。」

translations.literal: The emperor said: 'You seem not to match him.'

sentences.zh: 參曰：「陛下言之是也。

translations.literal: Cao Can said: 'Your majesty's words are correct.

sentences.zh: 且高帝與蕭何定天下，法令既明，今陛下垂拱，參等守職，遵而勿失，不亦可乎？」

translations.literal: Moreover Gaozu and Xiao He pacified the realm, laws and ordinances already clear, now your majesty hangs sleeves and does nothing, we and others guard our positions, follow without losing them—is this not acceptable?'

sentences.zh: 惠帝曰：「善。

translations.literal: Emperor Hui said: 'Good.

sentences.zh: 君休矣！」

translations.literal: You are excused!'

Cao Can's son Jiu served as middle grandee. Emperor Hui was surprised the prime minister did not handle affairs, thinking 'Is it that he despises me?' He then told Jiu: 'When you return, try privately and leisurely ask your father: 'Gaozu has newly abandoned the ministers, the emperor is young, you serve as prime minister, daily drinking, having no affairs to request, how do you worry about the realm?' However do not say I told you.' Jiu having bathed and returned, while attending, privately followed his instructions to remonstrate with Cao Can. Cao Can was angry and caned Jiu two hundred strokes, saying: 'Hurry and enter to attend—the affairs of the realm are not for you to speak of.' At court, Emperor Hui reproached Cao Can: 'Why did you cane Jiu? It was I who sent him to remonstrate with you.' Cao Can removed his cap and apologized: 'Your majesty yourself examine—whose sagely martial qualities compare with Gaozu's?' The emperor said: 'How would I dare aspire to the former emperor!' He said: 'Your majesty observe—whose ability compares with Xiao He's worthiness?' The emperor said: 'You seem not to match him.' Cao Can said: 'Your majesty's words are correct. Moreover Gaozu and Xiao He pacified the realm, laws and ordinances already clear, now your majesty hangs sleeves and does nothing, we and others guard our positions, follow without losing them—is this not acceptable?' Emperor Hui said: 'Good. You are excused!'

sentences.zh: 參為漢相國，出入三年。

translations.literal: Cao Can served as Han prime minister for three years coming and going.

sentences.zh: 卒，謚懿侯。

translations.literal: He died, given the posthumous title Marquis Yi.

sentences.zh: 子窋代侯。

translations.literal: His son Jiu succeeded as marquis.

sentences.zh: 百姓歌之曰：「蕭何為法，顜若畫一；

translations.literal: The people sang of him: 'Xiao He made the laws, precise as if drawn by rule;

sentences.zh: 曹參代之，守而勿失。

translations.literal: Cao Can succeeded him, guarded without losing.

sentences.zh: 載其清凈，民以寧一。」

translations.literal: Carried his clarity and purity, the people achieved peace and unity.'

Cao Can served as Han prime minister for three years coming and going. He died, given the posthumous title Marquis Yi. His son Jiu succeeded as marquis. The people sang of him: 'Xiao He made the laws, precise as if drawn by rule; Cao Can succeeded him, guarded without losing. Carried his clarity and purity, the people achieved peace and unity.'

sentences.zh: 平陽侯窋，高后時為御史大夫。

translations.literal: Marquis Pingyang Jiu during Empress Gao's time served as superintendent of trials.

sentences.zh: 孝文帝立，免為侯。

translations.literal: When Emperor Wen was established, he was dismissed to become marquis.

sentences.zh: 立二十九年卒，謚為靜侯。

translations.literal: He reigned twenty-nine years and died, given the posthumous title Marquis Jing.

sentences.zh: 子奇代侯，立七年卒，謚為簡侯。

translations.literal: His son Qi succeeded as marquis, reigned seven years and died, given the posthumous title Marquis Jian.

sentences.zh: 子時代侯。

translations.literal: His son Dai succeeded as marquis.

sentences.zh: 時尚平陽公主，生子襄。

translations.literal: Dai married Princess Pingyang, fathering son Xiang.

sentences.zh: 時病癘，歸國。

translations.literal: Dai fell ill and returned to his state.

sentences.zh: 立二十三年卒，謚夷侯。

translations.literal: He reigned twenty-three years and died, given the posthumous title Marquis Yi.

sentences.zh: 子襄代侯。

translations.literal: His son Xiang succeeded as marquis.

sentences.zh: 襄尚衛長公主，生子宗。

translations.literal: Xiang married Princess Chang Wei, fathering son Zong.

sentences.zh: 立十六年卒，謚為共侯。

translations.literal: He reigned sixteen years and died, given the posthumous title Marquis Gong.

sentences.zh: 子宗代侯。

translations.literal: His son Zong succeeded as marquis.

sentences.zh: 征和二年中，宗坐太子死，國除。

translations.literal: In Zhenghe year 2, Zong was implicated in the crown prince's death, the state abolished.

Marquis Pingyang Jiu during Empress Gao's time served as superintendent of trials. When Emperor Wen was established, he was dismissed to become marquis. He reigned twenty-nine years and died, given the posthumous title Marquis Jing. His son Qi succeeded as marquis, reigned seven years and died, given the posthumous title Marquis Jian. His son Dai succeeded as marquis. Dai married Princess Pingyang, fathering son Xiang. Dai fell ill and returned to his state. He reigned twenty-three years and died, given the posthumous title Marquis Yi. His son Xiang succeeded as marquis. Xiang married Princess Chang Wei, fathering son Zong. He reigned sixteen years and died, given the posthumous title Marquis Gong. His son Zong succeeded as marquis. In Zhenghe year 2, Zong was implicated in the crown prince's death, the state abolished.

sentences.zh: 太史公曰：曹相國參攻城野戰之功所以能多若此者，以與淮陰侯俱。

translations.literal: The Grand Historian says: Chancellor Cao Can's merits in attacking cities and field battles could be so many because he was together with the Marquis of Huaiyin.

sentences.zh: 及信已滅，而列侯成功，唯獨參擅其名。

translations.literal: When Xin was already extinguished, while the marquises achieved success, only Cao Can monopolized the name.

sentences.zh: 參為漢相國，清靜極言合道。

translations.literal: Cao Can as Han prime minister, his clarity and tranquility reached the extreme of accord with the Way.

sentences.zh: 然百姓離秦之酷後，參與休息無為，故天下俱稱其美矣。

translations.literal: Yet the people after departing Qin cruelty, Cao Can participated in resting them with non-action, thus the realm all praised his beauty.

The Grand Historian says: Chancellor Cao Can's merits in attacking cities and field battles could be so many because he was together with the Marquis of Huaiyin. When Xin was already extinguished, while the marquises achieved success, only Cao Can monopolized the name. Cao Can as Han prime minister, his clarity and tranquility reached the extreme of accord with the Way. Yet the people after departing Qin cruelty, Cao Can participated in resting them with non-action, thus the realm all praised his beauty.
